content: I was trying to search for META issues in Github but it sucked in a lot of unrelated issues. Maybe I just don't understand how to do a literal search in Github (which means lots of other people don't either). Regardless, it might make it easier to keep tabs on META issues if we had a label. Thoughts?
I'm neutral on the suggestion, but I have noticed the github search seems to favor new issues with a keyword more than the relevance of the keyword itself.

https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+%5Bmeta%5D+in%3Atitle

backdrop/backdrop-issues
Issue tracker for Backdrop core. Contribute to backdrop/backdrop-issues development by creating an account on GitHub.
@BWPanda I ended up doing that too but it's not obvious. I think it's still worthwhile having a label

I think @jenlampton will disagree... She doesn't like having too many labels :wink:

I think that for the amount of times we need to do this, we can just use the search option (or even make a short URL specifically for listing Meta issues)
@jenlampton who do you agree with? @BWPanda or me?
I agree with @bwpanda. I think until we can get different types of labels from GitHub we should try to have as few as possible so that new contributors won't be discouraged from using them.
